text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with black Cumberland sauce that's
right we're doing a darker and I think
more delicious version of the classic
holiday fruit sauce and of course this
was named after the Duke of Cumberland
who by most historical accounts was
kinda jerk but nevertheless this sauce
is so delicious and perfect for those
rich holiday meats so let me show you
how to do this now we're calling this
black Cumberland for three reasons the
first of which is going to be some
blackened onions so in a little bit of
vegetable oil I'm going to put 1/2 cup
of finely minced onions along with a
pinch of salt and a heavy saucepan on
medium heat and I'm going to cook those
until they're almost black I know the
scare some of you but don't be scared
this is really important and you know
what this spoon is too big for the shot
let me switch to the freakishly small
heat proof rubber spoon Yola and you
don't have to stir this constantly but
stir it very often keep it moving so
that's going to take a few minutes to
get as dark as we want while we're
waiting let's go ahead and test our
citrus a very critical part of the
recipe
so I'm going to use one of these
Esther's you've seen me use these before
it makes nice long strands of zest it's
only gonna get that first layer which
has all the essential oils all right so
I'm gonna do two oranges and a lemon and
I guess you could grate it if you had to
but then you're going to get fine little
pieces and it's just not going to be the

in a lemon by this time our onions
should be just about right and this is

and by the way that's not going to cause

which is kind of silly because it's so

to gauge so just let it boil and bubble

heat so it doesn't go down too far okay
and then it's time to add the next black

bad news is Cumberland sauce purists are

news there's no such thing as come
Lenz's puris so we're okay at that point
we can go ahead and toss in our zest and

all right freshly cracked you can see

going to add just a little touch of

it off that's it super super simple
recipe and you're going to be shocked by
how much flavor is packed into this
sauce it's really really good all right
now you have a decision to make you can
serve this hot okay you can serve it
just like that just like you would any

let this cool down all the way and serve
it as a condiment like a cranberry sauce
it's going to really thicken up and get
beautifully dark and glossy all right
you can see that there it's going to get

all when you put this into your ramekin

it almost looks black alright so this is

course I'm not going to stop there I'm

well that's exactly what it was and it

how good this is going to be on goose or
